webTitle: Manufacturing data: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: While December's production figures show a welcome upturn, economists remain cautious over the rest of the year's prospects
fields.body:
UK factories enjoyed much stronger output growth than expected in December and Britain's trade gap narrowed, boosting hopes recession could be averted.

Manufacturing output rose five times faster than expected, up by 1% on the month in the strongest growth for seven months, according to the Office for National Statistics.

The ONS also reported that Britain's trade deficit narrowed more than expected. But the improvement was not driven by the kind of growth the government has been espousing. Imports of goods fell while exports edged up only slightly.

Following are economists' views on the data:

Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit

Like the production numbers, the official trade data follows the recent upturn in the business survey data, which took so many by surprise, and we therefore expect to see increasing numbers of overly gloomy analysts start revising up their growth forecasts for 2012 in the light of these better-than-anticipated numbers. However, the prospects for the UK economy still look sombre for the rest of the year, and growth is likely to be patchy and lacklustre as better manufacturing performance is offset by weak consumer spending.

Lee Hopley, chief economist at manufacturers' organisation EEF

December's production figures show the fourth quarter wasn't a complete write-off, with the strong rebound in manufacturing output hopefully providing a solid platform for continued recovery in the first quarter. In line with a lot of positive reporting and anecdotal evidence we are continuing to see some strong sector performances, especially those with long lead times and exposure to emerging markets.

The UK's trade data shows that some sectors are continuing to benefit from strong export demand, particularly in non-EU markets. Overall goods exports reached a record level at the end of last year, making some headway into the overall trade deficit and pointing to encouraging signs of rebalancing across the economy. It is critical this trend continues through 2012, given the reliance on net trade and investment to drive GDP growth this year.

Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight

December's appreciable bounce in manufacturing output is very good news; and together with the improved January survey evidence, boosts hopes that the sector is past the worst and is on course to return to growth in the first quarter, thereby helping the overall economy to also return to growth.

However, it needs to be borne in mind that December's rise in manufacturing output followed six successive months of falling production and the sector still faces a very challenging environment. So questions remain as to whether the sector can sustain its improved performance around the turn of the year.

Looking through some recent volatile trade data, there is little real evidence of underlying marked improvement, and doubts persist that stronger exports can boost overall growth and help the UK economy to become more balanced.

Indeed, serious concern remains that UK exports will be limited for some time to come by the problems in the eurozone and muted global growth.

Alan Clarke, economist at Scotiabank

Overall, a positive set of data – albeit a little backward looking. That said, if there were two areas of the economy that one would want to see an improvement in, external trade and manufacturing would be at the top of the list.

Jens Larsen, chief European economist, RBC Capital Markets

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee will have received these data in time for its decision today: the impact on the decision and next week's inflation report forecast is marginal, but the flow of positive data is, in our view, consistent with the MPC signalling a halt to purchases in next week's inflation report.

Nida Ali, economic adviser to the Ernst & Young Item Club

These figures further reduce the chances of a technical recession. However, short-term growth prospects are still dominated by downside risks and the eurozone crisis continues to cast a shadow on the outlook for exports and manufacturing. The domestic economy is struggling against high unemployment and fiscal austerity, making the UK heavily dependent on exports to power the recovery.

It is noticeable from these figures that our trade position with non-EU countries improved significantly over the latter months of last year. With the outlook for European markets remaining uncertain, the onus will be on UK exporters to continue efforts to tap into faster-growing emerging nations.

Osman Ismail, Centre for Economics and Business Research

While the industrial production figures represent a slightly improved December compared with recent trends, caution should be exercised. Domestic demand for industrial output remains subdued, and export orders from our largest trading partner, the euro area, are muted amid the ongoing financial troubles there. While the sector has experienced an increase in demand from non-European markets, such as China, Brazil and the US, this may not be enough to reverse the trend of declining industrial output.

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce

On trade data: while we should not give too much weight to one month's figures, this is still a welcome development and supports our view that a recession is unlikely. Although the rebalancing of the economy towards exports is moving slowly, it is reassuring that we are heading in the right direction.

On manufacturing data: these figures are stronger than expected and support our belief that the UK economy will avoid recession. The sector's overall performance has been relatively weak in recent months. However, the December upturn is positive as it comes in the face of a tough austerity programme at home, and difficult challenges facing UK exporters in the eurozone.

webTitle: BG cuts back on fracking for shale gas as prices slide

fields.standfirst: Oil and gas producer joins US rivals Chesapeake and ConocoPhillips in scaling back controversial production process
fields.body:
BG Group has become the latest major energy giant to scale back on shale gas production amid falling prices.

The oil and gas producer, created by a demerger from British Gas 15 years ago, has joined US rivals Chesapeake and ConocoPhillips in cutting back on the controversial production process known as fracking, where a combination of chemicals, water and sand is pumped into the ground to hydraulically fracture or "frack" the rock and release trapped gas. However, concerns over the process have not been a factor in the companies' decisions.

BG said on Thursday that its production target for US shale gas would be 80,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day [boepd] in 2015, more than half the previous estimate of 190,000. The group's chief executive, Sir Frank Chapman, said a decline in the US gas price – known as the Henry Hub price – was the main reason behind the move. A gas discovery boom in the US has driven down prices in the domestic market.

BG said the number of its US shale rigs would fall from 35 to eight this year as production is slashed. Chapman added that the move represented a "deferral" of production, with output expected to rise to 190,000 boepd by 2020. "By the time we get to 2020 we expect similar levels once again," he said. "This is a deferral of the programme, given that we see, at least for the time being, a period of lower prices."

Despite the recent announcements, shale gas is a key factor in predictions that the US will be almost self-sufficient in energy by 2030.

According to a BP report published last month, the country faces a future where it will be markedly less dependent on oil and gas supplies from the Middle East.

It also predicted a growth in resources "including US shale oil and gas, Canadian oil sands and Brazilian deepwater, plus a gradual decline in demand, that would see [North America] become almost totally energy self-sufficient" in two decades.

BG owns a stake in some of Brazil's most promising offshore oil prospects, but Chapman would not be drawn on reports that the group was considering selling part of its stake to China's Sinopec. When pressed on speculation of a partial disposal, which reports say could raise more than $20bn (£13bn), he said: "We are very happy with our project in Brazil."

The shale announcement was made alongside strong fourth-quarter figures for BG. The group also reaffirmed its target of growing oil and gas production at 7% per year to 2020, despite weak US gas prices. It said fourth-quarter earnings, which exclude one-offs and non-cash charges, were $1.48bn against analysts' forecasts of $1.11bn.

JP Morgan said even stripping out the impact of the low tax rate, BG outperformed expectations by 8%.

webTitle: Aquarius Platinum falls after production problems in South Africa hit its results

fields.standfirst: Safety stoppages and industrial troubles hit South African platinum miners
fields.body:
Platinum is in the spotlight on worries about South African production and disappointing results from a major producer.

Aquarius Platinum has fallen 5.9p to 156.6p after the company said revenues for the six months to December fell 25% to $253m, with production down 14% after safety stoppages and other problems at its South African mines. It made a loss of $113m including a $91m foreign exchange loss. Chief executive Stuart Murray said:

Our financial results do no more than reflect the ongoing difficult operating and trading conditions facing the company and the southern African platinum industry.
At our results for...December 2010 I said we were through the worst and thought the bottom was behind us in this sector. I could not have been more wrong.

Andy Davidson at Numis Securities said:

[The] interim results makes uncomfortable reading, with operating costs appearing higher than consensus. Well-flagged operational issues and lower quarter on quarter production were highlighted in the second quarter production report – the higher mining costs and lower realised platinum group metal prices are brought out here.

Meanwhile Lonmin might have to review its 2015 targets if safety stoppages and strikes continued to hit South African production, the company told Reuters. Its shares are flat at £10.51.

webTitle: Recession fears ease as manufacturing rebounds strongly

fields.standfirst: Economists say new figures add to evidence the UK could post at least some growth this quarter and avoid recession
fields.body:
UK factories enjoyed much stronger output growth than expected in December and Britain's trade gap narrowed, boosting hopes recession could still be averted.

Manufacturing output rose five times faster than expected, up by 1% on the month in the strongest growth for seven months, according to the Office for National Statistics.

But economists cautioned that the fourth quarter of 2011 as a whole saw an even bigger slump for industry than first thought, leaving the overall economy on shaky ground.

Against that backdrop the Bank of England announced that it would inject a further £50bn of fresh electronic cash into the economy, taking its quantitative easing (QE) programme to £325bn.

Opinion was divided over whether that would be the final instalment of QE from the bank, given signs that consumers remained under pressure but business had improved across all sectors at the start of this year.

The end-of-year rebound for manufacturers chimed with a closely watched business survey last week suggesting that they went on to enjoy a further pick-up in activity in January. Economists said that added to evidence the UK could enjoy at least some growth this quarter and avoid recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of economic contraction.

Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, said: "Data from the Office for National Statistics add to signs that the worst may be over for the UK economy and that a double-dip recession will be avoided."

"We expect to see increasing numbers of overly gloomy analysts start revising up their growth forecasts for 2012 in the light of these better-than-anticipated numbers."

The official data showed the wider industrial sector, which includes mining and utilities, enjoyed a 0.5% rise in output in December, above forecasts for 0.2% growth. Still, that was not enough to turn around industry's fortunes for the final quarter of 2011 as a whole.

Statisticians said that they had revised down their estimate for industrial production over the October to December period but that this would have only a minor downward effect on overall GDP, which they estimate dropped by 0.2% in the quarter.

Manufacturers' organisation the EEF said there were now signs from its members that a recovery was under way. "December's production figures show the fourth quarter wasn't a complete write-off, with the strong rebound in manufacturing output hopefully providing a solid platform for continued recovery in the first quarter," said EEF chief economist Lee Hopley.

"In line with a lot of positive reporting and anecdotal evidence we are continuing to see some strong sector performances, especially those with long lead times and exposure to emerging markets."

Still, demand from both emerging and other overseas markets in December failed to provide any significant boost to exports, according to separate data from the ONS on Thursday.

It reported that Britain's trade deficit narrowed more than expected. But the improvement was not driven by the kind of growth the government has been espousing. Imports fell while exports edged up only slightly, in a blow to ministers' hopes of rebalancing the economy towards overseas demand away from domestic consumption.

That pattern left Britain's global goods trade gap at £7.1bn, below a forecast for £8.6bn and the narrowest in almost two years. Exports were up 0.9% while imports fell 4.6%.

"The December trade data are encouraging overall with the total deficit narrowing much more sharply than expected," said Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight. "However, the underlying picture is not quite so promising. The main reason behind December's narrowing in the trade deficit was a marked fall in imports, which points to weak domestic demand.

"Looking through some recent volatile trade data, there is little real evidence of underlying marked improvement and doubts persist that stronger exports can boost overall growth and help the UK economy to become more balanced."

webTitle: Rio Tinto's Tom Albanese says that he doesn't want a bonus

fields.bodyText: The head of the global mining group Rio Tinto has become the second FTSE 100 chief executive in as many weeks to voluntarily forgo his bonus. Tom Albanese, who received salaries, bonus and benefits of $2.97m (£1.87m) in 2010, said he would waive his bonus entitlement after Rio was forced to take a $9.3bn charge, largely in relation to its $38.7bn acquisition of Alcan in 2007. High raw material costs, stuttering growth and strong competition from Chinese rivals left the deal for the Canadian-based aluminium firm far short of Albanese's expectations. On Thursday, Rio wrote down the value of this division by $8.9bn and said a number of underperforming assets would be sold off. The total value of Rio writedowns on Alcan is now about $18bn — half the value of the acquisition. Albanese said: "Growth in demand for aluminium remains strong but the industry has been running surpluses for the past five years. Chinese production is still tracking internal demand, but has shifted more toward the north-west, where coal is being used to generate electricity. "As the acquisition of Alcan happened on my watch, I felt it only right not to be considered for an annual bonus this year." It is unclear what Albanese's bonus would have been, but his maximum entitlement was $2.8m. He received cash and shares totalling $28.1m (£17.75m) in the four years after the Alcan deal. He received more than half of that — $15m — in 2010. The Rio boss admitted, with the benefit of hindsight, that "the price that we paid [for Alcan] was very high". He claimed that before the financial crisis few had realised the business world was about to be transformed. "The world is quite a different place right now." Albanese declined to directly answer whether waiving his 2011 bonus was a proportionate response, given cumulative writedowns of $18bn. Instead he repeated: "It was on my watch. I think it was the appropriate thing to do." Sarah Wilson, of corporate governance group Manifest, said: "Clearly the company has recognised there are shareholder concerns. I am sure shareholders will welcome that. But there may be some shareholders who feel that this is not enough." Last year 26% of Rio shareholders voted against the group's boardroom pay arrangements. In 2010, the opposition vote was even higher, at 37%. Shareholders were particularly angered by Rio's decision to raise the potential bonus payouts to executives from 120% of salary to 200%. Rio said it would "increase the competitiveness" of short-term incentives. The move by Albanese to forgo his 2011 bonus follows the decision by the Royal Bank of Scotland's chief executive, Stephen Hester, to waive his entitlement last week after months of pressure from executive pay campaigners and politicians. RBS's woes, like those of Rio, stem from a record-breaking takeover battle at the peak of the bull markets in 2007. In the case of RBS, the battle was with Barclays over the Dutch bank ABN Amro; for Rio it was a tussle with Alcoa over Alcan, one of the world's biggest aluminium manufacturers. Rio bought Alcan two months after Albanese was promoted to chief executive of the mining group in May 2007. The deal was described by the then chairman, Paul Skinner, as "transformational". He told investors the purchase "demonstrated the strength and depth of Rio Tinto's managerial capability to deliver value to shareholders". Albanese received a 2007 pay package worth $3.57m. Rio's current chairman, Jan du Plessis, said he backed Albanese's decision. "Whilst we have today reported excellent underlying earnings numbers, we also have to recognise that we have taken a significant impairment charge in relation to our aluminium business. As this charge largely relates to the acquisition of Alcan, Tom Albanese and [finance director] Guy Elliott have notified the remuneration committee that they did not wish to be considered for an annual bonus and I think that is absolutely right." Rio's net earnings for last year dropped 59% to $5.8bn as a result of the heavy writedowns. However, the group said underlying revenues were up 11% at $15.5bn, with record $27.4bn cash flows from operations. As a result, Du Plessis announced a 34% increase in Rio's full-year dividend to $1.45 a share.

Rio bought Alcan two months after Albanese was promoted to chief executive of the mining group in May 2007. The deal was described by the then chairman, Paul Skinner, as "transformational". He told investors the purchase "demonstrated the strength and depth of Rio Tinto's managerial capability to deliver value to shareholders". Albanese received a 2007 pay package worth $3.57m.

Rio's current chairman, Jan du Plessis, said he backed Albanese's decision. "Whilst we have today reported excellent underlying earnings numbers, we also have to recognise that we have taken a significant impairment charge in relation to our aluminium business. As this charge largely relates to the acquisition of Alcan, Tom Albanese and [finance director] Guy Elliott have notified the remuneration committee that they did not wish to be considered for an annual bonus and I think that is absolutely right."

Rio's net earnings for last year dropped 59% to $5.8bn as a result of the heavy writedowns. However, the group said underlying revenues were up 11% at $15.5bn, with record $27.4bn cash flows from operations. As a result, Du Plessis announced a 34% increase in Rio's full-year dividend to $1.45 a share.

webTitle: Enterprise Inns says it could raise up to £200m from property sales to cut debt

fields.standfirst: Pubs group identifies further asset sales as trading continues to improve
fields.body:
Enterprise Inns has jumped more than 7% after the debt-laden pub group issued a positive trading update and said it could raise £200m from asset sales this year.

The company said average income per pub was up 5% in the 18 weeks to the beginning of February, although the comparative trading period last year was hit by the snowy conditions which cost the company around £2m in lost profits.

It has sold most of its underperforming pubs and expects to raise £50m from disposals in the normal course of events. But it has identified a number of unwanted properties which could raise another £150m this year.

Its sale of 63 pubs so far this financial year means it has cut its borrowings from £446m to £420m.

Enterprise continued to call on the government to act to protect community pubs which it said provided valuable employment for young people. It said the duty escalator should be dropped, and steps should be taken to discourage supermarkets selling cheap alcohol.

Trading will continue to be tough, it said, but it hoped to benefit from continuing to improve its estate. Meanwhile it has appointed Robert Walker, currently at Travis Perkins, as its new chairman.

Enterprise has added 3p to 45.25p and analyst James Dawson at Charles Stanley said:

Previously, we have argued that the group's estate valuation has been ahead of equity price valuations and we believe that this statement underlines this once more. The encouraging trading signs from the pubs do need to be viewed in the context of a more buoyant set of sector updates this year, as weather this year was milder. However, the group has managed to capture this performance and thereby the beneficial cash impact. We retain a buy with a speculative caveat attached.

But Paul Hickman at Peel Hunt was less impressed:

Enterprise has a long-term debt management task on its hands. Its immediate hurdle of refinancing bank facilities, expiring December 2013, has become more achievable on increased disposals. However, uncertainties on substantial longer-term repayments, and debt service in the meantime, must still be taken on board by any investor wanting to take a position. Despite the low PE, we still believe the risk profile is too great for most.

webTitle: Diageo dips on profit taking after cautious comments, but FTSE edges higher

fields.standfirst: Drinks group reports 9% rise in operating profits, as emerging markets outweigh weak European sales
fields.body:
Diageo, the drinks group whose brands include Johnnie Walker and Guinness, has dipped as investors decided to take profits after cautious comments from the company.

Its half year earnings per share rose 16% while operating profit climbed 9% and volumes grew 3%. The company said growth in emerging markets and a recovery in the US made up for weakness in Europe. Chief executive Paul Walsh said:

We are cautious as to the consumer and economic trends we will face in 2012 but these first half results have positioned us well.

But with the recent strength in the share price, that was enough to see it edge down 6p to 1455.5p. Analysts were still mainly positive though. Martin Deboo at Investec - who recently raised the idea of corporate action at the company including a possible disposal of Guinness - said:

Diageo have delivered a positive interim result this morning, with organic net sales and operating profit growth at the higher end of the consensus range. Investors should be encouraged by strong trading in the US, as well as continuing momentum in developing and emerging markets, though Europe remains a mixed bag. With no change to the ambitious medium term guidance, we believe Diageo remain on track to deliver against expectations and we remain comfortable buyers, with a £17 target price.

Phil Carroll at Shore Capital said:

Diageo is an interesting stock, in our view, because it continues to be seen as a defensive company but we would highlight that with its growing emerging market exposure – currently around 33% of sales but targeting 50% over the next 4-5 years, it is also becoming an emerging market growth story too and a structural growth story from the perspective of a growing spirits market. We acknowledge that with the stock being at all time high levels the short-term upside may be more limited but we believe the medium-term investment case remains solid and therefore, we reiterate our buy recommendation.

On a big day for corporate news, not to mention the eurozone crisis, the FTSE 100 has moved 21.37 points higher to 5897.30. Today sees meetings at both the Bank of England and the European Central Bank, with the former tipped to discuss further quantitative easing. The ECB will be widely watched, not just for its interest rate decision but comments about the current situation in Greece and its attitude towards its investments there and further bond buying.

Among the companies reporting, BG is topping the FTSE risers, up 38p at £14.84, but Rolls-Royce has lost 20p to 765p.
